Comment: Myth #4: "Peak Oil is dead, buried at the Bakken."

Few people believed that Peak Oil was a valid concern, even as prices escalated during 2007 & 2008. Today we are "awash in oil" and PO is universally regarded as a classic example of alarmism. Human ingenuity prevailed, as it always will. Resources are not a constraint because we clever humans will find substitutes and adapt. 

In the case of North American oil & gas supply, fracking saved the day. Canada and USA now have so much tight gas that they should engage in large-scale overseas exports. USA has so much tight oil that import dependence will surely be a thing of the past, so much so that DOE should sell off the Strategic Oil Reserve. And the PO 'theory' was merely the paranoia of ill-informed Chicken Littles.

Serious analysis of global energy and climate change should reflect an understanding of the scientific literature regarding oil and gas supply. Concern over our long-term oil & gas supply is far from a dead issue.

Comment: http://www.globaldrugpolicy.org/Issues/Vol%201%20Issue%203/A%20Critical%20Evaluation.pdf

THE JOURNAL OF GLOBAL DRUG Policy AND PRACTICE
A Critical Evaluation of the Effects of Safe Injection Facilities 
Garth Davies, Simon Fraser University

Conclusion: Taking Causality Seriously
On the subject of the effects of SIFs, the available research is overwhelmingly positive. Evidence can be found in support of SIFs achieving each of the goals listed at the beginning of the evaluation. In terms of our level of confidence in these studies,the assessment offered here is far less sanguine. In truth,none of the impacts attributed to SIFs can be unambiguously verified. As a result of the methodological and analytical problems identified above, all claims remain open to question.

Let alone the possibility of how much life could be out there.

Comment: The new discoveries (naledi being only 250,000 yrs old etc.) are extremely interesting, but prof.Berger's anthropo-centric interpretations (human relative, deliberate burial, distance runner, tool making) are outdated (pre-darwinian): naledi was most likely a fossil bonono-like ape, but with more humanlike feet (full plantigrady) & smaller front teeth. The fossil was found in mud-stone (which fossilizes in +-stagnant water, e.g. wetland & forest swamp). Naledi's curved hand-bones show frequent vertical tree-climbing. The flat feet (very unlike ostrich & kangaroo) suggest frequent wading, like bonobos do when wading bipedally for shallow aquatic herbaceous vegetation (AHV), google "bonobo wading". The small anterior dentition suggest abrasive or calorie-poor foods (AHV), google "Pan naledi 2017 Verhaegen".

Comment: Congratulations on your newly emerging maturity and ability to get right to the nub of the objectives and the issues that matter.

In earlier days, you would have blamed PM Stephen Harper as the guilty party behind Trump's state visit, his speech, and also for Islamic radical terrorism not to mention male pattern baldness.

To get back to reality for a nanosecond (you can revert your eyes), Trump's 9 day multi-nation and NATO excursion is well chosen strategically but is also an extremely ambitious, strenuous schedule for a 70 year old head of state.  I recall when our PM Louis St. Laurent went on a similar foreign tour in 1954 at age 72.  He became exhausted and ill on the tour and never really regained his previous stamina and energy.  

Trump's current tour - certainly off to a successful start - can be summed up as "The I'm Not That Apologetic, Mealy Mouthed, Wishy Washy, Leading From the Back of The Bus, Abominable Obama Guy Tour".   

That, for now, is good enough.

Comment: As a political science major, I find it odd that you're not familiar with the current scientific consensus on voter ignorance.  Are you a first-year student or something?  Are you not familiar with voter ignorance, rational irrationality, and public choice theory?  To my knowledge, there is no paper, study, or evidence of any kind which suggests that increasing the total number of ignorant voters actually leads to better outcomes.  That has more to do with faith in democracy than any actual science.

Don't get me wrong, there is also no evidence to suggest it will lead to worse outcomes either.  There is no reason, in principle, to be against automatic voter registration, but not being registered is not the reason that most people don't vote.  

"Democracy works better when more people participate"

Where is the evidence for this claim?

"Consent of the governed" is an oxy-moron.  It would be like saying "consent of the rape victim."  If it's governed, it's not consensual.  It's force.

Comment: Maybe it is time to quit laying charges for marijuana possession.

Per Stats Can "Drug-related offences in Canada, 2013" 
- Cannabis possession accounts for more than half of all police-reported drug offences.
- More than half of all completed drug-related court cases involved cannabis
- Half of all cannabis-related cases involved a single charge

While the over-all crime rate has dropped significantly over the past 25 years, drug offences have continued to increase.  Despite the over-all crime rate decline decline, the rate of police-reported drug offences was 13% higher in 2013 than it was a decade earlier in 2003 . In total, about seven in ten (71%) police-reported drug offences in 2013 involved drug possession. While the rate of cannabis possession (168 per 100,000) remained relatively stable from 2012 (+1%), it was 28% higher than it was in 2003, and more than double (+114%) the rate in 1991.

Trudeau has decreed possession of marijuana charges will continue to be laid.

An accounting firm in downtown Calgary has employees.  It has premises. Comment: Then there was the time I was walking to school with my buddies and we were playing 'ice-breaker' in the frozen ditches. It was my turn to take the lead, but hit a patch of ice that did not want to break. Forward momentum took me down face first on the ice (which then uncharitably decided to break). I was soaked from head to foot.

I went back home to change and my mother was preparing to give me a quick lesson on safety with the hairbrush when my Uncle (her brother) on visit from England intervened and pleaded on my behalf. I got off with a stern and loud lecture, along with a conditional glare that said, wait until next time.

I learned that ice is only your friend when wearing skates (or in a drink in summer) and, 2) always have allies when facing the enemy.

Comment: I think we've gotten a bit away from the point.  Sometimes people say health care is a 'right' when they mean "people have a right to be able to afford healthcare".  I certainly don't believe anyone has a 'right' for someone else to pay for their care.  But that is in reality what we had before ACA.  People who paid nothing for health insurance used the hospital emergency room when sick or injured, and if admitted would pay only what they could afford, if anything.  Everyone else had their bills padded to pay for the indigents.  After ACA more people paid into the system and bills were spread more evenly.  I believe it encouraged individual responsibility, and I know people felt more secure.

Comment: A cynic would claim that all the big environmental organizations are exploiting the fears engendered by the rhetoric of the next administration solely to push for grass-root-based donations. I'm hopefully not that cynical. But when considering how to respond to all those funding drives, it occurred to me that it might make dollars go further and make these groups ultimately more effective if there was some umbrella super-org that coordinated policy initiatives and resource allocation.  I am cynical enough to believe that this is probably beyond the reach of groups led by fiercely independent activists (herding cats), but some effort in that direction seems needed if any headway is to be made against an administration that has shown it can unify the opposition.

Comment: Then live your life accordingly. Nobody is stopping you from doing that. 

But deciding that laws should be based on 'what's sinful' is a bad ideology. This simplistic thinking causes more harm than good by going along with ideas like the war on drugs where you take sick hurting people and throw them behind bars. It's sickening and I don't think it aligns at all with what Jesus or the broader religion of Christianity teaches. The government isn't here to enforce The Bible on society. It's there to protect life and liberty, and until you have some sort of evidence that something is threatening life or liberty there's really no good reason to ban it.

Note that I didn't say health and liberty, I said life and liberty. You go down a slippery slope when you argue that "well cannabis/alcohol/guns CAN be unhealthy" the point is that they're not in the majority of cases. Where they are a threat to life (driving intoxicated, shooting in city limits) should be illegal. ALWAYS protect children.

Comment: I don't question a political agenda, but I do think the headline in the print version is sensationalizing. For example, it says "Oregon teachers' pay tops other in region" but the sub heading is "insurance and benefits surpass some districts in Washington and Idaho, a study finds."
Instead the headline could be "Oregon teachers' insurance and benefits trail others in region." This is what the first paragraph states when it says compensation is higher than SOME districts. That means it is also lower than SOME districts. 
The second paragraph says that the "high cost of those benefits means..." Isn't "high" a subjective term? Wouldn't "higher costs" be more neutral and accurate? 
Finally, a more detailed examination would have indexed compensation with cost of living. How do I know teacher pay in Beaverton is relatively that much higher than Vancouver? In fact, cost of living indexing might prove teachers in Oregon are actually paid more in real dollars than in "some" areas.

Comment: I'm a current student, and I wrote a response to this article on medium which you can read here: https://medium.com/@charlottealexandra/not-fragile-flowers-25f592903daf. Letting this article go unaddressed publicly and be taken at face value, unquestioned, could only further feelings of isolation and internalized stigma that often already accompany mental health challenges. Articles like this one have the potential to keep young people from accessing the support they need and deserve-- something that can actually already be so hard to come by on campus (as a student, I've experienced this as have many of my peers). I really hope we can work toward a system where empathy is more of a focus than competition, and where students don't have to fear being stigmatized by their professors and other post-secondary faculty for mental health challenges.

Comment: Hello On-Line reader,

Nope, when house prices in a Canadian city reach dozens of times the average annual local income, as in Richmond and Vancouver, that is NOT local job wages, and that IS overseas money at play.

You make the mistake of assuming that overseas money gets here only in the hands of "foreign buyers".

Nope. Most got to Vancouver through investor immigrants, rich new Canadians who bought citizenship by handing over lots of cash. Quebec is still running such a program, bringing in the better part of ten thousand new rich home-buyers a year, folks who then buy in Vancouver and Toronto.

It is silly to believe that the realtor's self-reporting (roll eyes) is catching and reporting all of the overseas money flooding into Canadian real estate.

A better indicator for Vancouver and Richmond is student make-up of schools in the expensive neighbourhoods: Over a couple of decades, from less than 5% to suddenly over 70% having facial features consistent with Chinese ancestry.

Comment: Whales seldom ground by accident. Ocean acidification from excess carbon we dump into the system (creating carbolic acid) has destroyed the base of the food pyramid, the krill and other mini-crustaceans that support salmon, whales, and hence orcas & seals, so that mass die-offs are occurring more frequently. That whale does not look fat by any means. 
Is it possible it grounded because it was weak from starvation and feared drowning? It likely it will come ashore again, or die at sea. We are in the midst of the greatest mass-extinction event since the dinosaurs checked out, but as long as we can drive our huge internal combustion vehicles we'll be like the frog sitting in a pot of water slowly brought to a boil, & since we don't notice the change, & perish.
The Yellowstone caldera is ready to erupt so all bets are off, even if we corrected all our errors overnight. The Hindus & Mayans both believe human civilization has reached an apogee many times before & collapsed so we're overdue.

Comment: To think any Canadian city can compete with the American one is a pipe dream.  This morning on CNBC the pundits talked about one possible site other than the American cities listed in this article - Northern Virginia in the Washington D.C. metro area.  It doesn't have a 'city' per se but the vast sprawling area spreading over two counties have well over 1 million people, a major airport (Dulles), high way system and metro train into D.C.  It is among the richest area in the country, offers quick access to winery and mountain getaway in the Blue Ridge Mountain area.  It will easily attract the educated and tech class who will have good disposable income to enjoy the mid to upper middle class life style this area can offer.  And it is closed to the power center of the country, D.C.  My money is on this area (although Baltimore is not far behind).

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

Comment: What did a semen-stained blue dress from the Oval Office have to do with a land deal in Arkansas? After a couple of years of digging, that's all a partisan prosecutor could find against Bill Clinton. 
There's nothing unconstitutional about a prosecutor working an investigation finding evidence of other, related or even unrelated crimes. And of course, it's constitutional to pursue those other crimes. 
Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down. 
Say a judge signs a search warrant based on evidence of an illegal poker game in Joe's basement. The cops come in and find they're not gambling, but there is an ounce of cocaine on the card table. Do they walk out and say: "Darn, too bad the warrant's for illegal gambling. Now we can't make a case for the cocaine."
Same as a prosecutor investigating MAFIA underlings to build a RICO case against the mob boss. She may use a drug case as a means of gaining cooperation.

Comment: As someone who ran for City Council in the last primary (against Amanda Fritz) and would have more than likely benefited from publicly financed elections, I'm opposed to bringing back this program. What I learned from my own campaign is that there's a learning curve to getting elected that is akin to on-the-job training for holding office. Raising money is tough, sure, but it also helps you hone your message, learn how to connect with voters, and to listen to all of their concerns, hopes and dreams for Portland. There were 31 people running for the three open seats, and while there were some great people, many were unqualified to hold public office. No amount of money from public coffers would have changed that, but it might have masked it. More importantly, though, it would be immoral to take $145,000 for a 10 week primary cycle when that is just slightly less than the cost of getting someone who is houseless off the streets and into affordable housing. For me, the choice is easy.

Comment: Part 2

But it was not settled. Pope Innocent had died in March 417 and the new pope, Zosimus, proceeded to reopen the case, and to make noises favorable to Pelagius. It was eventually the emperor Honorius who condemned Pelagius, and Zosimus followed the emperor's lead and condemned Pelagius in the summer of 418.

However, Zosimus himself died in late 418 and Pelegius tried to reopen the case again. This time Augustine used lay contacts (and a hefty bribe) at the imperial court to come down against Pelagius.

Thus, the actuality is that Rome spoke several times, saying different things, and the case was not settled for several years. And, incidentally, it was the emperor who really made the determination, not the pope.

Comment: So, you're basically saying, "move the capital to Anchorage" which already feeds on more government than Juneau.     Unlike Anchorage, Juneau, as the historical capital, has actual memorial features of territorial and state formation.   Anchorage was founded later in the 20th century and has a comparatively short history.   Further, Juneau at least tries to cultivate its private sector; it has mines, fishing, tourism, timber.   Anchorage has primarily military, and government with very little private sector industry other than oil sector management and freight handling.   It is Anchorage--not Juneau--that is the center of government-dependency and parasitism.  Shut down redundant state government offices in Anchorage.

Comment: A simple 15 minute walk outside during lunch does wonders, as well as vitamin D gel caps, every day to balance the mood.

Mine own advantage is as a medical courier, I am out and about all day, and therefore do not suffer unto the lack of daylight at all, as I am out within it all day long, and do feel most fervently unto those that are stuck inside for the most part of the day, which is why I recommend the lunchtime walk, at least, unto those that work the daytime shift indoors.

Comment: It is useful to recall that the original Canada-US Free Trade agreement (which was later folded into NAFTA when Mexico became a member) had as its cornerstone a commitment from Canada that we would sell our oil to the US at the same price as in our domestic market and that we would never give priority to domestic purchasers if supplies became tight.  

It would be a bit rich under these circumstances for the US to now put a tariff on Canadian oil imports.  It would also be contrary to US treaty obligations unless Canada agreed to the tariff or the US gave the requisite prior notice that it was withdrawing from NAFTA.

I'm really surprised to read and hear so many implicitly misleadeing reports of potential unilateral US tariff initiatives contrary to NAFTA without acknowledging that the US itself would have to forego the current benefits under NAFTA etc. in order to make such a change.

Comment: Perhaps members of the Board of Game should take a  "field trip" to the Denali Hwy and see what they have created. I quit visiting the Denali Hwy in the Fall over 20 years ago just when off road vehicles were becoming the favored mode of travel. One of those track vehicles was chewing up the tundra just off the hwy. These motorized "fun machines" are in our towns, too. Most accessible public lands now have impassable swaths unless you have one of those machines. Forget hiking & biking, skiing or dogsledding because the trails are way too rutted. The vegetation has been destroyed and no longer can I hop on my bike with a couple of buckets in my backpack and pick cranberries near my home. The wildflowers are gone because the land is simply a  continuous mudbog. Once kids and families got their exercise by walking and biking in the woods or along the shoulder of the roads. Now, there are more and more zipping by on their machines. How does that promote health of the land or body?

Comment: Health risk from DU continues for a long time ONCE released into the environment. Its half life is 4 1/2 billion years, but it is environmental release (not half life) that increases risk.  Once released, the damage accumulates over the lifetime of an exposed individual and for the earth. However, there is time to limit dissemination into the environment/air.  

How? Stop stirring up dust.  Stop fragmenting large DU bits into aerosolized dust. Collect and pave/gravel/plant over contaminated fields.  And by all means stop using the DU weaponry (worldwide).  

But if there is denial that DU has been used, we ask for a survey to reassure the public that there is no threat.  Already there are insinuations that Hawaii's risk is minimal compared to risk in the mid-east wars.  But remember - health risk and damage resulting from DU in mid-east wars has been significant. Hawaii should avoid any health problems resulting from preventable exposure. Two wrongs don't make a right. 

the Authors

Comment: Despite the fact that Western Canada oil producers can ship their crude oil (if not mixed with U.S. products) to foreign countries using U.S. port facilities in the Gulf Coast area, the volume of Canadian crude oil (essentially light crude) amounts to about 25,000 barrels per day, which represents roughly 0.8% of Canada's total crude oil production.
Canada has an almost complete reliance on the U.S. market for its heavy crude oil exports. Increased pipeline capacity in the U.S. allows to get more Canadian heavy crude oil  to the U.S gulf Coast area where the largest number of refineries in the world that can process Canadian dilbit are concentrated.
According to the U.S. Energy Information Administration (IEA), U.S crude oil imports from Canada in 2016 reached a new level with an average of 3.25 million barrels per day. It reached a peak of 3.56 million barrels per day last November. That same month Alberta lost 13.000 jobs. Building new pipelines won't bring those jobs back.

Comment: Ms Townsend, I fear you haven't kept up with your legislators. Oregon gives every drunk driver a free pass once per decade. It also doesn't actually punish the second offense in that time frame and the third is a small fine and temporary, partial suspension of driving. (A waiver to drive to work and shopping is almost automatic.) Also, we still call these negligent acts "accidents". A drunk who doesn't flee the scene is very unlikely to come away with a criminal conviction. In fact, just a couple of years ago one of your neighbors went out to a strip bar, spent hundreds of dollars getting drunk as can be, ran over a pedestrian (dead) and was sentenced to no jail time even though he drove away and passed out on a nearby on-ramp, so even fleeing is no guarantee of jail.

I do so wish you were right about the impact of MADD, but our culture still too readily accepts the massive CARnage imposed on us by intoxicated motorists without creating adequate legal sticks to fight back with.

Comment: Justin Trudeau, and therefore the Liberals, gained great international and domestic praise and notoriety during their first months in office for the dramatic and youthful flare (in growing contrast to other quarters) but this created expectations that could not be realized.  Unfortunately, Trudeau appeared to relish his notoriety (and appear too needy) a bit too much too often and this coupled with the natural difficulties of governing a complex country like Canada and the difficulties of our times generally make Trudeau and the Liberals vulnerable to a negative recoil from earlier, perhaps excessive, expectations and premature praise.

As this reaction began, Trudeau made the tactical mistake of going into non-stop campaign mode when the appearance of working hard in Ottawa might have served him and his Party better.

Trudeau & the Liberals are not in serious trouble politically or in terms of social policy but they need to rethink their public presentation to remain really effective.

Comment: Define "associated with terrorist"-- I have a hard time with this.   

If I'm not mistaken, there are many ways that people who want to use these powers for their own purposes could "square the circle".   One would hope that judges would see through this, but you never know what circumstances could arise around a warrant being sought.    And then, by the time anyone in an oversight role gets involved, it could well be too late, or crucial details obscured behind smoke and mirrors that would expose wrongdoing.

When I read this stuff, it makes me think of the cladding on the Grenfell building.   Just as it seems multiple "checkpoints" broke down with the cladding for the Grenfell, this legislation has checkpoints (oversight, judge's warrant).   However, those checkpoints can break down and be subverted, just as what happened with the Grenfell.   And, like the Grenfell, it will take a tragedy for people to take the dangers associated with the weaknesses in this legislation seriously.

Comment: That was a good read.   It shows we have to careful to link a particular factor, (like owning shares or not owning shares), as having a causal effect on voting patterns.     I was surprised the preferences were as close as they were.   

Stock ownership is hardly an even playing field.   It's one thing to 'let it ride' in a retirement account hoping for modest retirement support.   It's quite another to have the extra income that gives you management/investment advice with the goal of creating wealth.   As in most things, wealth  increases your opportunites of success through mulitiple support structures, and this would include stock investment. 

I don't see any tax policy that changes that basic dynamic.   Government programs are hopefully designed to provide greater opportunity for those who would have very little otherwise.    It's why we've come to associate great wealth with 'privilage'.    Inequality of opportunity is a fact, not a statement of ideology.

Comment: Fixing a disaster the size of the island of Puerto Rico will not be quick and easy.  Considering FEMA is coming off of two other major hurricanes, as well as efforts in the US Virgin islands the relief efforts are doing as well as can be expected.  They can and will do more.  For the media to Monday morning quarterback this will not help and at this juncture is not fair.  The question why was Puerto Rico was not better prepared to help themselves is a fair one.

The lesson to be learned is Oahu could become like Puerto Rico if a Cat. III or higher storm hits us directly.  We would be without power, water, phone services, and others for weeks if not months.  We do not have enough or adequate shelters.  We are even more isolated from the CONUS than Puerto Rico.  Rescue efforts would take longer and be more problematic.  Rebuilding would take way longer than a coastal state in the mainland.  What are our elected leaders doing to mitigate this now?

Second, wait as long as it takes for the officer to tell you what he wants you to do.  Above all, do NOT move until he tells you to, and then only to comply with his instructions as closely as possible.  Do not try to be "helpful" by doing anything else such as drawing or touching your weapon.  This Mr. Castile apparently failed to do.

Be smart and live another day.

Comment: I would suggest that the current crossing safety measures are very adequate WITHOUT the train horns.  The issue is not that individuals don't know a train is coming.  The barriers are "down", the lights are flashing, the bells are ringing.  Persons who are struck by trains at such crossing knowingly disregard the existing warnings and barriers.  They're in a hurry and don't want to wait for "that damn train", so they drive around the barrier, ride their bike around it, or walk around it......after all they will "beat" the train to the crossing.  Breaking news: at such crossings the "tie" always goes to the train.

Those loud, obnoxious horns are appropriate and needed at rural crosssing where there are no barriers and,often, are no signals.  Having trains sound those horns at each crossing in a city is unnecessary.  Requiring millions of dollars to "up-grade" the crossings is unnecessary.  What's necessary?.......that people quit being so "stupid" in decisions to ignore the warnings...

Comment: In this discussion, PERS is a diversion, a red herring. PERS has been "reformed" (benefits reduced)over 20 times since 1995. The last attempt at "reform" was rejected by the Court, and since the legislature actually spent the money it were trying to take from retirees we are in a worse situation now. The Court has said definitely that unilateral retroactive changes to contracts are illegal. The legislature will have to stop funding state expenditures from the retirement fund. 

Measure 97 funds are by law going to schools (early - 12th grade), health care, and senior care. Will this over time alleviate the stress on the state budget and allow new revenues to be used for other purposes? Yes. But the retirement fund payments have to be made no matter what happens to Measure 97.

Comment: The Legislature fiddles while the state burns.

A shutdown would not only cost the state millions of dollars in economic and investment damage, but even laying off every state worker would end up costing the state millions of dollars. Because state workers are laid-off, not furloughed like federal employees in shutdown, the state is legally required to cash-out the employee leave banks of every single employee effected. You can safely assume hundreds of thousands of hours of leave would have to be written off the books with checks, and long-service employees who have climbed the payscale will get large payouts (a quarter million or more for some folks I know who have several thousand hours in the bank).

The brinksmanship is a bad joke. It doesn't get anything accomplished other than making our state government look as dysfunctional as the federal government. The Legislature needs to do its damned job.

Comment: I am a sports parent of a child with wonderful talents and abilities; he almost won a spot in the NFL Pro-bowl and he was selected at one point to attend our State’s Basketball Championship. He ranked #2. He’s probably what Donald Trump would call a winner. Some of my fellow parents do believe that their childrens’ abilities are their own products, talents that their kids – and no one else – created. What sports teaches us is that there is no I in team, that there is no place for huge egos on the court or the field, and that defense wins games. The thing that religion teaches me (and I hope taught my son) is that there is something bigger than the next Championship, Superbowl or whatever. That there is something bigger than you; that other people do matter, even if they are really, really, really bad at sports.  The president’s proposed budget and current proposed healthcare plan seem to be more about the kids with talent/money/luck and less about everyone in the USA. And that is sad.

Comment: "You can't invest the money the way you want."  It's interesting how many ordinary citizens are investment experts.  We don't fix our own cars, we don't cut our own hair, we don't record and listen to our own music, but we think making our own investment choices is better than having expert professionals do it for us.  
Not only are employer or union plans professionally invested, but by participating in them, you are "buying wholesale" instead of paying high retail prices at your bank.  The fee you pay as an individual is usually at least 1% or more than in a group plan.  That's 1% of the total value of your investments, every year.

Fans want the thrill of being 1st to cross the finish line, with every heart stopping moment and every breath taking spectacle that makes them cling to their seats and squeal for more along the way. That's football, that's entertainment and that's what fans love.

So damn the brakes, full speed ahead! GO BRONCOS!

Comment: Time to hunker down and tighten belts. According to a real estate appraiser that I'm acquainted with, the Mat-Su real estate market is still strong. I would imagine that Anchorage's market is weakening and we'll probably eventually see things slow down in the Mat-Su unless folks start dumping properties to migrate outside. 

This ain't our first rodeo - In 1986 in the midst of the last recession, I was looking at the possibility of a state job I had held for 10 years to be cut. As a belt tightening measure, I had to cancel a remodelling job that I had tentatively scheduled with a friend. He was a self-employed building contractor and loudly dismissive of "the guvmint". Other of his tentative jobs were cancelled for similar reasons. He went out of business. So much for the "public economy" vs the "private economy" - it's all one economy.

My "anti-guvmint" buddy went on to get a job with the state. I went on to start my own business. Go figure....

Comment: I am not sure how this will be implemented.  The main failure of this initiative is that there is not enough detail in what is being proposed. The BC carbon tax seems to have worked OK (?). The economy as a whole will see no change unless the tax revenue is saved or leaves the country. Governments need revenues to pay for necessary benefits such as public education and health care. These will paid for whether with government taxes (deficits) or private fees. How will the carbon tax work with the existing tax structure? Infrastructure spending needs funds. If we need infrastructure we also need a source of funds to pay for it. These are new expenditures so a new tax would seem to be required. Maybe we don't need new infrastructure, i. e. gridlock forever.

BTW Trump proposes infrastructure spending and without new taxes. Maybe a carbon tax would make sense if he does what he has proposed. I guess those people who like the Trump approach have no problem with deficits!

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

I hope JT has a sense of humour.

Comment: Outsider:  Damn it, man, I really enjoy arguing with you, and on this one it's really hard.  With population growth, urbanization and industrialization in, as you point out, especially China and India, our "carbon footprint" just keeps growing.  The best we can do is to try to "slow it down."  Unless there's a concerted and coordinated worldwide commitment to address all the factors (including population growth), we're doomed to ever-increasing and ever-accelerating warming. 

Yes, we should do what we can to slow it.  But, at the same time, we'd best make significant strides toward needed long-term adjustments to live with it as best we can.  That includes such things as decreased "waste" of water, and reassessing what locations are habitable....especially, already extremely dry areas and very low elevation and vulnerable coastal regions.  It won't be pretty.   Regards, Gary

Comment: Back to the main point.  I think your characterization of traditional Hawai`i in such negative terms stems from misunderstandings similar to those that puzzled Cook and his crew.  Your bizarre take on the sexuality of the Hawaiian women, which wasn't shared by Cook's sailors, evokes the New England missionaries to Hawai`i.  It was an eye-opener for me to read your words.  I thought such extreme ethnocentrism was long gone.

The practice of archaeology has led me to admire the genius of Oceanic peoples in general and Hawaiians in particular.  I recently used my training as an anthropologist to investigate some misunderstandings between the British and kanaka maoli, as reported in the diaries of Cook and his officers.  I wrote up the investigation in the hope that it would help historians get past some of their ethnocentrisms, so they might glimpse a bit more of Hawaiian genius.

Comment: You're massively overstating the downside of M97 while ignoring the upside.  Hits "most retailers" "extremely hard"?  Only 3 percent of C corporations will pay the tax, and most retailers aren't C corporations.  The percentage that's "hit" is extremely small.  Some retailers will raise some prices, but the net effect of all that may be less than 1 percent overall, which amounts to a random fluctuation in the inflation figure -- one which we hardly notice.

Try to keep in mind how much improvement we can make in the future lives of our school kids when we provide them with a quality education, rather than huge class sizes and the nation's shortest school year.  Isn't that worth paying a tiny fraction more at the store?

 Happy New Year to old friends on St. Paul.

Comment: Simple fact, employee related expenses as well as the expense of automation that replaces many of those workers are tax deductible.  This means that 'tax cuts' will not change the companies decisions regarding their employees.  If an employee can 'add to the bottom line' the company will tend to hire that person.  Tax cuts will not change this.

When a company needs to spend money to buy things or hire people to make money, they only pay taxes on the profit made, and they get to deduct the cost of materials needed.

The only effect that tax cuts will have is on the amount of their profit they get to stick in the bank.  After all, if they reinvested that money, it would not be taxed.  This extra banked money does not go to the government, putting more financial pressure on the government.  Employees do  not benefit, only the top brass and the owners of the company profit from lower corporate taxes.

If you want to compete with China on the basis of wages, expect a MUCH lower standard OL

Comment: In the interest of understanding each other, I will include my comments as they were written for this article.

Hi Rachel,

In brief, I have quite a few concerns about the Commissioner's approach, namely that pursuing density without adequate protections in place to prevent displacement and invest in community stability for existing residents (in particular low-income renters, communities of color) puts us on the wrong path to being the next San Francisco where hardly anyone of modest income can afford to live. Our governments and the market have thus far failed to stem displacement in our rapidly gentrifying city, and we continue to lack the tools necessary to increase density in a way that accounts for displacement. I fear that the city of Portland will finally achieve a "sustainable, equitable" city, but only once the vast majority of low-income residents and communities of color are pushed outside the city limits. <continued in next comment.

Comment: "There is power in the idea that any citizen can go before the Eugene City Council and speak his or her mind on any subject"  City Council meetings, school board meetings, and all public body meetings are, essentially, "captive audience venues."  The idea that such meetings should first open with three minute "open mike" comments on "any" topic is totally insane.  Perhaps, once or twice a month, the Council or any other public body should advertise and hold such a "non-agenda comments" event with everyone having a chance to address any topic they choose.....That could be both cathartic and entertaining.  However, public bodies should actually have a published agenda for a meeting and focus on addressing the issues and items on the agenda.  Citizens should be invited to speak to the agenda items as they arise. If public input is to be more than that catharsis for the speakers, it should be focused on the actual topic being discussed.  Gary Crum

Comment: Ecumenical councils ARE the supreme law of the Church.  It has always been.  When the first Ecumenical Council at Nicaea [325 AD] occurred---and the Second Council at Constantinople I in 381 AD. the doctrine that the assembled bishops [NO POPE was in attendance] crafted became the Nicene Creed that we recite today.  

The big thing that came from Vatican I was that of Papal Infallibility on matters of faith.  Dei Filius was the only other document passed at this council [the bishops got away as fast as they could from Rome--because of the impending Italian force stood ready to defeat the Papal States which they did].

"Dei Filius" discussed the nature of God, the need for revelation, the nature of faith and the relationship of faith to reason.   Not all the ecumenical councils were dogmatic; Lyons I--1245; Lyons II---1274; Vienne, 1311-12; and the ecumenical council held during the Great Western Schism in Constance---1414-18.

Comment: Chris

Site C is the third large dam on the Peace River. WAC Bennett was Site A, Peace Canyon was Site B. 

In addition there is Mica Dam, Revelstoke Dam, Kootenay Canal and Seven Mile Generating Station. 

There are also a number of other smaller dams that generate power that are not 'run of the river' style of generating stations on the Columbia/Kootenay river system as well as a few that I am aware of in the Lillooet region of the province. (Seton Lake and Carpenter Lake area)

There are even some large dams in the Kootenays on the Columbia/Kootenay that do not generate power that control water flow to support the other generating systems. 

Note that the largest, most damaging hydro electric facilities are on major rivers that are the furthest from the population centers in the lower mainland and southern Vancouver Island.  This is not coincidence I am sure. 

Example, why no hydro dams on the Fraser River?  Can't say 'salmon' because they destroyed the runs in other rivers.

Comment: "The users of a product, whether it’s a park, a university or a road, wind up paying for a higher share of its cost, instead of everyone chipping in for the general public good."
Please tell me what's wrong with that?

There's nothing wrong with it...assuming you don't believe in the very concept of government or the social contract.

We all benefit from good roads.  We all benefit from an educated populace.  We all benefit from open space and parks.  Even if you never use the services, they serve a purpose.  And when we start restricting their use to a privileged few, that purpose is not as well served.  

From a rational free-market viewpoint, one of the key functions of government should be to ensure the existence of important services and programs which the private market is either unable or unwilling to serve.  Moving to a fee-based model ignores that purpose, turning the government into merely another competitor in the market place.

Comment: To answer your first question, here is how descendants are determined today.  

"'Lineal  descendant'  means  with  respect  to  Native  Hawaiian  skeletal 
remains,  a  claimant  who  has  established  to  the  satisfaction  of  the 
council,  direct  or  collateral  genealogical  connections  to  certain  Native 
Hawaiian skeletal remains" HAR § 13-300-2.

"'Cultural  descendant' means ... with  respect to Native  Hawaiian skeletal 
remains,   a   claimant   recognized   by   the   council   after   establishing 
genealogical   connections   to   Native   Hawaiian   ancestors   who   once 
resided or are buried, or both, in the same ahupua‘a or district in which 
certain   Native   Hawaiian   skeletal   remains   are   located   or   originated 
from." HAR § 13-300-2

Where the rule says "council" it refers to one of the island burial councils.

My guess is Kaleikini is a cultural descendant in this case, so does have rights under the law.

Comment: Because small scale hydo is going to work on rivers that freeze almost totally solid in the winter?

I'm not opposed to hydro projects, but any of the old timers who remember the Chatanika dam can attest to this. The Chatanika dam was used to provide head pressure for the Davidson Ditch until it washed out during the 67 Flood. It also provided electricity for the Chatanike Gold Camp ... in the summer. Come winter, the flow of water would become next to useless.

Large scale hydro can overcome some of that difficulty, but there's a reason why we've been pushing for Susitna all these years rather than the Rampart project on the Yukon. Susitina still has flow even in winter. The Yukon's flow is practically non-existent.

So, solar won't work in the Interior in the winter. Wind only works if you live in Delta or Healy. Small-scale hydro won't work in frozen rivers. We need the electricity in the winter, not the summer and storage is not very efficient. So .... still fossil fuels & wood.

Comment: 18 U.S. Code § 371 - Conspiracy to commit offense or to defraud United States
If two or more persons conspire either to commit any offense against the United States, or to defraud the United States, or any agency thereof in any manner or for any purpose, and one or more of such persons do any act to effect the object of the conspiracy, each shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than five years, or both.

That statute would include prohibiting conspiracy to impede the lawful functions of government, which would include administering an election, and agreements to commit any other crime, such as hacking computers, or any election laws.

Comment: While not expressly forbid, it would appear as though Donny Boys use of this public land does not meet the intent of the rules established here which are vague but specify a range of recreational uses that are "generally" allowed:

https://www.oregon.gov/dsl/NAV/Pages/navigwaterways.aspx

I have very little legal knowledge, but if it were possible, wouldn't it be interesting if some enterprising individual with the means to do so, sued the city in Federal court for violation of federal laws, based in their failure to enforce rules aimed to prevent interference with the public use of the waterway for navigation commerce, recreation or fisheries  (i.e. failure to prevent formation of illegal permanent dwellings on public water ways).

From the 2005 legal opinion from DOJ:
"Federal and state law limit the discretion of the state to alienate its ownership, to the extent that doing so would interfere with the public use of the waterway for navigation, commerce, recreation or fisheries."

Comment: This is very reminiscence of how she has handled the electricity price issue.  High prices, caused by her parties misguided policies, have people upset.  So what is Kathleen Wynne's solution?

First to introduce a "benefit" for lower income families to cope with high prices.  The problem?  It is a step-function benefit.  If your total family income (for a 3 or 4 person family)  goes from $48,000 to $48,001 your benefit drops from $420 or $480/year to $0.

Then, to top it off, she is "saving" us money by remortgaging the contracts, costing more in the long-run in order for a very short-term savings.  Finally she "removed" the Ontario Provincial tax, requiring the revenue to be made up for using other taxes.

It's just being one mistake after another to "fix" a mistake her party made.  Now she is looking to do the same thing with labour costs.

The French could have easily defeated the Germans, and removed Hitler from power, but they didn't - they sat back and watched as the Germans grew stronger, and before long, it was too late. 

Today, the US and its allies sit back and watch Kim develop nuclear-tipped ICBMs. And, they do nothing. Very, very soon, it will be too late.

Each experiment brings the North Koreans one step closer to their goal of building nuclear-tipped ICBMs that will reach North America. Once that happens,  it is a matter of when - not if - but when a nuclear missile from North Korea flattens a city in Japan, South Korea, the US or Canada. Make no mistake, it will absolutely, certainly happen. 

Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it. We, evidently, have not learned a damn thing.

Comment: Actually, that is precisely why the 2nd was insisted upon as a condition of ratifying the Constitution by a handful of the States. What was being proposed, a strong central government granted its own power to levy and collect taxes, was, rightly, viewed with great caution by those who had only recently escaped the tyranny of the last central government. The security of the State mentioned was the security of the individual States, not the general government. The security of each State in the United States depended upon the citizens of that State being armed and well trained in the use of those arms. The common defense of all depended upon those State militias being willing to fight alongside of each other if any of the States, or all of them, were threatened.

Comment: I was born in Kakaako in 1937.  Moved to Kalihi when I was about 8.  My memory is a community of diverse cultures, household heads being grandparents. Pidgin the 3rd. Language of the children who played together.  No sidewalks, just good, old dirt to play marbles. Mixed in, a candy factory on the corner of the block.  Naval supply depot (use to be a race track), barbed wire fencing about 2feet from the house we used to hang the wash.  Ice truck came by once a week, and the Manapua man selling his  buns and dim sum.  An rooms-to-let apartment complex owned by a Russian man. Kodak's big building where I use to slide down its smooth, concrete ramps.  This was a neighborhood, a village, a wonderful place to call home.

One can only marvel that someone with Tillerson’s interests at heart did not stop him from going out to grovel and affirm admiration for a president who has continually undercut, contradicted and diminished his secretary of state. Former State Department official Eliot Cohen via email dubbed the performance "servile."

Former ambassador Eric S. Edelman concurs. “The press appearance was the most humiliating, degrading performance by a secretary of state that I have seen in my lifetime. He was clearly ordered by the White House to go out and lavish slavish praise on the president.”

Comment: I work at a specialty feline hospital that refuses to declaw, and volunteer with an all cats rescue. I have also previously volunteered with another cat shelter, and worked as a staff member at a third. I also worked at a different cat hospital for a year that did declaw. This procedure has been proven by several professional studies, most notably, the American Veterinary Medical Association published a study done by Cornell Medical University stating 1 in3 , 33% of declawed cats develop behavioral issues. I have been working in both the veterinary field and the shelter system for over 3 years specifically with cats and have seen firsthand cats lose homes from behavioral issues caused by declawing i never seen a cat lose a home from scratching. This is outlawed in several countries. Cities that banned declawing saw a DECREASE in cats surrendered to shelters. I find this article not only noneducational but appalling andis spreading FALSE information on how a ban would effect cats.

Comment: We're actually talking about two types of purchases here:  legal ones and black market (and often illegal) purchases.  The efforts by "gun control" advocates is to close loop-holes in the legal purchases.  References to expanded background checks and the inclusion of the "no-fly" and "watch list" data base are efforts to keep persons who might pose a danger from legally acquiring firearms.  You can argue that they would not be effective....fine, they wouldn't be 100% effective.  Some persons would still fall through the cracks and others would seek black market purchases.  We know that.  However, these background check proposals pose no threat to legitimate firearm ownership.  Additionally, they might serve another positive purpose.  If an individual were placed on the "no fly" list and didn't know it (which is likely, until he/she tries to fly), an attempt to purchase a gun would alert them and they could address the issue if they felt they were wrongly on that list.

Comment: Yes, but more. Science also explains why there are two sexes (and not three or more), and also offers explanations to why not every component aligns 100% of the time. They are rare misalignment ("error" has negative connotations) from typical development following the mathematics of natural selection and reproductive success, whether genetic cases (e.g., XXY instead of XX or XY), physical development (e.g., hermaphrodites), different psychological gender identity (e.g., transgendered, non-binary), or even sexual orientation (e.g., homosexual, bi). Understanding why these cases occur, currently to varying levels, doesn't negate the underlying principle of binary sexes. Likewise, the existence of different types of colour blindness doesn't mean there aren't 3 primary visual colours. 

There's nothing morally wrong with any of the exceptions, and they have equal individual rights against discrimination, but nobody else can compel speech or ruin careers over individualized pronouns.

"The dots are clear now," she writes.  And the first "dot" she lists, I believe, is the crucial one: "the untreated anxiety as a child that led him to self-medicate ..."  I may be naive, but "self medication" doesn't start until the person's able to do so--as, perhaps, a young teenager.  It's that untreated "anxiety"--a vague term--that appears to be the (childhood) problem here.  Yet, the focus is on what came next: drug abuse.  By then, I suggest, it was too late.  

About half-way through the piece I started looking for a mention of the root cause...and finally found it near the end.  "...in treating substance-use disorder and concurrent mental-health disorders..."  Concurrent?  Probably. However, Jordan appeared to have manifested symptoms years before "substance-use disorder."

Comment: "Investors have been migrating in droves in recent years to ... fee-based advice" -- Mr. Mckenna thinks because it's cheaper?  Nonsense.  Jornos just don't understand this issue.  Regulators' interference always leads to the opposite of the intended effect. Neither ETFs nor fee-based charges result in lower fees to Advised investors, it's all about re-packaging.  Cost of advice is driven by market forces; over-regulation increases cost and restricts choice for investors. You think advice should be accessible and cheap?

There are tens thousands of advisors; surely, at some point they would compete on price left to their own devices? and they do! Price for advice varies dramatically among institutions, within institutions, geographies, affinity groups, type of advice, style of investing, etc.

Trailer fee is a red herring. Switching to ETFs is a coincidental, not causal relation to Canadian fee environment. Fee-based advice is a style of a relationship, neither superior nor inferior.

Comment: It's  obvious that Trump continues to use in inappropriate international trade diplomacy the tactics honed during a lifetime in the rough and tumble of New York high stakes (and often shady) real estate dealing.

Happily, the Canadian Cabinet and senior civil servants appear well prepared not only to counter US assertions but also to advance Canada's interests at the most advantageous time and place. Similarly, aside from the odd aspirant to the Conservative leadership, both the Conservative Party and NDP are united with the Government to protect our interests.

The tactic (a sound one) at this stage is to (a) politely blow off the petulant tweets and throw-away comments, (b) publically continue to refer to past assertions from US quarters that the US will be reasonable in the end, and (c) prepare to fight hard when real negotiations begin in a few weeks time.

There's nothing to be gained by following Trump down the rabbit hole of his "good cop, bad cop, mad cop" efforts to distract.

Comment: Laura, 
I feel it necessary to inform you that your point of view is rather old and needs a modern re-examination.  No ID proponent has a problem with microevolution, because it is statistically possible, (2 base pair mutation in single celled and single mutational event, in a mammal, for example).  These are entirely expected, the math supports it.
Was cannot be supported, are multiple mutations required for a Selectable Advantage, this is certainly a requirement for macro evolution.
Much recent work has revealed many Latent genetic and regulator instructions, in all life, that change the organism when stressed.  The changes follow a predictable pattern, when creatures are stressed in the same manner.
The Evolution Revolution, by Lee Spetner, lists many specific examples of this.
What appears to be going on, are environmental adaptations brought about, by built in information, not the gradual accumulation of micro evolution. 
Reality suggests, creatures preloaded with information.

Comment: “Any sign should be low key. Something you don’t even see.”

In regards to individual donors, it's a nice unobtrusive acknowledgement of their contributions, something for the passerby to stumble upon.

In regards to organizations and businesses, branding is most effective when it's embedded into the everyday seemlessly. If we "discover" that a park is sponsored by X group, we implicitly garner more positive feelings towards X group.

I'm more wary of things that are low-key, because subtlety is the most powerful tool there is in rooting and manipulating behaviors and emotions in people.

Comment: She's dealing with the idealism of a principle she's not critically or honestly engaged.

Equality of opportunity is really a matter of liberty. Is your person free (from external compulsion) to do as you choose with the means attributable to you? Government is in charge of compulsive force, so to the extent that it *acts* to produce "equality", it's necessarily curtailing some personal liberty (viz. what you can do with the first quarter of your income, etc. etc.).

Equality of social outcome (including educational attainment) thus comes at the *expense* of equality of opportunity, thanks to the built-in unfairness of biology. 

If we want equality of outcomes, or at least the alleviation of the worst inequality, then let's at least say so. I am all for high quality education for all! But we have a better chance of achieving an end if we're conceptually clear on what it actually is, and what it entails.

Comment: The 'Hillary' polls were accurate - she DID win the popular vote - which is all polls do - reflect people's opinions as the people give them.

It was the distribution of some of the votes (totally about 70,000 over 4 'swing' states) that moved the Electoral College which, as you well know, has NOTHING to do with the will of "the people". Systems that give ALL EC votes in a 'winner-take-all' system like the EC simply serve to eradicate up to 49.9% of "the people's" actual votes. (eg. T-rump had fewer than 12,000 more votes than Hillary in Michigan.) The EC renders the votes of people in lesser-populated states worth up to EIGHT times more than those in heavily-populated States - and, as a 'winner-take-all' system, it can make them worth 100% more.

When 70,000 voices of "the people" can 'trump' (you should pardon the expression) those of 11,119,386 other "people" (the total MORE people who voted for someone other than T-rump), something is amiss.

Sad that you revel in it.

Comment: The Hawaii Supreme Court is performing great outreach in many aspects, like working with India's environmental law leaders, bringing the court sessions to Hawaii's public schools and so forth.

However, we need more due process to ordinary citizens in Hawaii in terms of HRS 343 and the way it's being processed.  Most of the public, including attorneys, do not know about the rigid short timeliness in an Environmental Assessment or Environment Impact Statement process. The reality is citizens don't go around reading fine prints in newspaper or in the Office of Quality Environmental Control or  the public library. Not many attend Neighborhood boards or community associations which are generally elected by dismal tiny amount of voters, with no dispersion of information beyond.  

Those who prepare the EA or EIS are not licensed or belong to any professional organizations. The public loses standing if they missed the deadlines. The irreparable damages are severe, with no standing in court.

Comment: I was once opposed to the concept of lot splitting, for similar reasons as some Edmonton residents express here.

But the City of Richmond BC, under pressure from developers, allowed new houses to be built almost to the side lot line,  and also allowed for massive set-backs.  These setbacks are popular for three car garages, and the City allows almost the entire front yard to be paved.
 
Now new build  homes dominate the lot.  The zoning for the property neighbouring us is  almost 5000 sq feet. It will sell for three million upwards. This is typical in the neighbourhood.

When completed, the house may be occupied for only part of the year, or not at all.  It is guaranteed to be under-occupied for the five bedrooms.

Far better that two homes be built.  There would be no difference to set-back or how far away the houses are to property lines.

In insisting that lots not be subdividable, Edmonton neighbourhoods should be careful what they wish for.

Comment: Hardly any women wore the burka in West Africa until two or three decades ago. 

However, at least 14 people were killed and 74 injured when a bomb went off outside a crowded market in Chad's capital N'Djamena on a couple of years ago. Nine of the victims were women who sold goods at the market, and another was a police officer. The suicide bomber, a man who concealed his explosives by wearing a woman's burka, was also killed.

Earlier this summer, a soldier from the country of Georgia and two Afghan civilians have been killed after a Taliban suicide bomber dressed in a burqa rammed his motorcycle into an international convoy.

A few years ago, a burqa-clad female suicide bomber in Pakistan lobbed hand grenades, then detonated her explosive belt among a crowd at an aid center, killing at least 45 people in militants' latest strike against the authorities' control over the key tribal region bordering Afghanistan.

Should the needed care not meet the insurance companies criteria the entire cost becomes out of pocket.

Comment: The argument is not simply to cut Medicaid, then do nothing, but to do something far more helpful for the poor and aged. The medical outcomes for Medicaid have been shown to be statistically no better than the uninsured:

https://tinyurl.com/ybg6dxju

Surely, we can do better with the vast sums we are spending, or simply leave the money in taxpayer pockets as opposed to flushing it down the drain.

Both Democrats and Republicans are failing on this, instead using health care as a political football. We should all be outraged at this and demand they stop all the hyperbole and redesign the whole system so it cannot help but succeed. Government should provide basic regulation and provision for the most poor, but the market should provide the choices for the rest of us. And we should take responsibility for our own choices that affect our health: smoking, drinking, drug use, obesity, and sexual proclivities. Those alone can cut costs by over two thirds for those who make good choices.

Comment: As I watched 9 more pre-orders roll in today, I had to think, darn, that's 9 more traction non-indicators for Steve.

Your opinion that pre-orders aren't a viable traction indicator is, frankly, nonsense. We clearly articulate preorders as "strong leads" in our offering circular. They are-- anyone who's put cash down, refundable or not, is a much stronger lead than someone who merely signs up for a test drive. Yes, we still have to build a compelling product, and continue to communicate that product to our pre-order customers. While some will certainly fall off, to me it seems likely they will more than be made up for from folks who are unwilling to place a preorder on something that is not yet in production, which is a very common refrain we hear.

Anyway, thanks for the positive home-town encouragement. Means a lot!

Comment: Actually enforcement in this city is extremely lax, I could sit at any intersection and would more than likely see numerous violations, of various levels, with an officer present, and more than likely never see a traffic stop. 

 I drive River Road at least twice a day, from Maxwell south to Roosevelt going west, since the change in signage, denoting a reduced speed in the area, average speed has if anything increased. I have yet to see a single stop from any department, city, county or state. I have witnessed numerous instances of children on bicycles, without helmets, with in more than one case more than one officer present, and nary a stop.

 Policing in this city has become reactive, rather than proactive, and we are seeing the side effects of such an approach. And no I am not currently up on Eugene's tactics or procedures, but I once was, and the changes I have seen taking place, aren't taking us to a better place.

Comment: Judging from that report, I'm not sure the economics around coal are the same here as they are in Germany -- Colorado coal (and  other places in the U.S.) is expensive because the easy-to-get seams were extracted long ago. The article characterizes Germany's as cheap, which I would assume also means relatively easy. Our's is hard and expensive to reach. And I think emerging technologies will play a role. As companies like Siemans dive into the deep end on battery tech, there could be some game-changing advancements. Either way, less is good. No one ever thought or proposed flipping a switch on fossil fuels. It's a process.

Comment: Christopher, the partners in the advisory section don't have to be CA.  They're not auditors; they're from a variety of disciplines including law, economics, finance, health, media, environment ... depending on the advice offered or required. The current (brand new) CEO is a management consultant with a human resources background. 

Its a far cry from when an audit firm was just that. Now its a business, and from there stems the conflict. The advisory section is more lucrative than audit which is constricted in value by time. Therefore the advisory partners serving the same large corporate as the audit staff serve, might hope the pesky questions from audit staff can be swept away lest they upset the lucrative advisory business.

The only solution is to disallow audit and advice offerings from within the same firm. And still rotate auditors every X years which would answer the question "who audits the auditors."

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: Most of what he will do if confirmed  would be done by any appellate judge of  either party.  He is also likely to, unlike Scalia, affirm federal pre-eminence in equal protection law - not that if he were to vote like hyper-Catholic Scalia it would make any difference - there are eight judges who go that way. Comment: Why would you assume that anyone would choose chemotherapy?  I have already informed my health-care provider that, were I ever to get cancer, I would not allow chemotherapy or radiation to be performed upon my body.  There are plenty of less-invasive, alternative therapies available, but the medical community would never consider them, just like it does not approve of CBD oil for depression and pain.  Everyone I know who has had cancer, and has had conventional therapies, has had the cancer chased to other parts of their bodies, or had it return with a vengeance.  They may have had a few-more years, but at what expense and with what quality of life?  A friend who has had breast cancer forced into remission is now confined to her sofa.  She has no strength, is tired all the time, and looks like death warmed over.  But she will tell you, proudly, that she "beat cancer."  Really?

Comment: It is even less than that too.  One might think it was 25% - 8% = 17% reduction on the cost of generating electricity, but it isn't.  It is more like 12%.

The 17% reduction in the cost of generating comes from the fact that they had originally planned to INCREASE the cost by 5% but instead are decreasing it by 12%.

In all it adds up to a 12% decrease on about half of your bill, so about 6%, plus the 8% provincial portion of the HST... which was added on by the Ontario Liberals in the first place.

And all paid for by future electricity price increases, tax hikes and debt passed on to our children.  To call this government "despicable" would be too nice.  This is the worst government in Canadian history at any level.

Comment: James Dickey:  I think you miss the point.  If 'bump stocks' were, by rule, turning a semi-auto into a full auto weapon, the bump stock weapon would now come under the same requirements as owning a fully automatic weapon.  Now let me ask you, given the choice between buying a manufactured fully auto weapon or the same gun in semi-auto and having someone install and set it up with a 'bump stock' thereby making it for all practical purposes a fully auto weapon, which one do you buy?  Bear in mind, with the simple rule changes already suggested, you would for both guns now have to go through the same application process plus pay the $200 a year tax on each.  Further, with the MFG fully auto you can set the selector to single shot and still have good accuracy from 400 to 600 yds, whereas the gun with the 'bump stock' can only spray on full auto all the time and the best score we got from the one we had was 10 inches at 100 yards, shooting 5 rounds (far worse using a full banana clip)?
